metadata.titleEn: 1:100,000 land use dataset of Tibet Autonomous Region (2000)
metadata.description: This data was derived from "1: 100,000 Land Use Data of China". Based on Landsat MSS, TM and ETM remote sensing data, 1: 100,000 Land Use Data of China was compiled within three years by a remote sensing scientific and technological team of 19 research institutes affiliated to the Chinese Academy of Sciences, which was organized by the “Remote Sensing Macroinvestigation and Dynamic Research on the National Resources and Environment", one of the major application programs in Chinese Academy of Sciences during the "Eighth Five-year Plan". This data adopts a hierarchical land cover classification system, which divides the country into 6 first-class categories (cultivated land, forest land, grassland, water area, urban and rural areas, industrial and mining areas, residential land and unused land) and 31 second-class categories. This is the most accurate land use data product in our country at present. It has already played an important role in national land resources survey, hydrology and ecological research.
metadata.instructions:
File name: data is stored in vector SHP format, and the file name is "Tibet-2000";
Data reading: it can be opened and read by remote sensing software such as ArcGIS and QGIS.

background: Land-use/cover change has become an event being of paramount importance to the study of global environmental change. Land-cover change is closely related to the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, i.e., the interaction between biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycle and sustainable exploitation of resources. The series of scientific study programs, issued and promoted by IGBP and IHDP in 1995, make the study of land-use and land-cover change (LUCC) become one of the hot topics in the global environmental change study. As a developing but booming country, China has formulated a series of policies exerting great influence on the land-use change. In addition, due to varied physical environments and vast land areas, its land-use changes not only influence the social and economic development but also impact the global change accordingly.
research objective: In this paper, the division of dynamic regionalization of land-use change is designed, for the sake of revealing the temporal and spatial features of land-use change and laying the foundation for the study of regional scale land-use changes. The paper exerts an effective effort on the integrated studies of “spatial pattern” and “temporal process” for land-use change to reveal the regional land-use change characteristics on the pattern of dynamic process and dynamic process of pattern.
challenges: It is too early to say that the trend of deforestation has been effectively reversed across China. There also exist conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, as showed in the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas.
dataset: The main data sources are Landsat TM digital images (520 scenes in 1995/1996 and 508 scenes in 1999/2000). Apart from that, the CBERS-1 (China-Brazil Earth Resources Satellite 1) data were also used to acquire land-use information for 1999/2000.
findings: There exists conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change in China, which lays the foundation to draw the dynamic zones. The rapid change of land-use change during 1995—2000 happened in North China, Loess Plateau—agricultural and pasturing interlaced area, Northeast China, southeast coastal region, middle and lower reaches of Yangtze River, eastern coastal region.

background: Land cover plays a significant role in Earth system science, which reflects the influence of human activities and environmental changes. Reliable and up-to-date land cover data are very important for land, ecological and hydrological modelling, carbon and water cycle study as well as global climatic change study. Many land use/cover maps at global, continental, and regional scales have been produced in recent years using remote sensing. These four global land cover maps are all derived from remote sensing data and created for the same fundamental purpose of providing improved land cover information for scientific studies and environmental monitoring, but they are different in mapping methods, data sources, and classification systems.
research objective: The objective of this paper is to evaluate the application of the four popular land cover maps over China land mass. The possibility of developing a new land cover map whose classification is compatible with a well-accepted legend system but whose accuracy is more reliable also motivates this study.
challenges: The four maps used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. We conclude that the accuracies of all the datasets cannot meet the requirements of land surface modelling. For the reference data, i.e. the 1:100 000 land cover map, the classification system needs to be transferred to a well-recognized one that has been used commonly in land surface modelling.
methods: We compare and evaluate four land cover datasets over China. So we first aggregated these maps by reclassifying them using a unified legend system. A large-scale, i.e. 1:100 000 land cover map of China was used as the reference data to validate the four maps.
dataset: The datasets include the Version 2 global land cover dataset of IGBP, MODIS land cover map 2001, a global land cover map produced by the University of Maryland, and the land cover map produced by the global land cover for the year 2000 (GLC 2000) project coordinated by the Global Vegetation Monitoring Unit of the European Commission Joint Research Centre. The large-scale (1:100 000) land use map of China in 2000, which was produced by Chinese Academy of Science to meet large-scale resource survey and land use mapping, was used as truth to validate the four land cover maps over China.
findings: The results show that the GLC2000 land cover map represents the highest accuracy. The MODIS land cover map ranks second for type area consistency and third for sub-fraction overall accuracy compared with reference data. The IGBP land cover map has good labelling accuracy, although it has a local labelling error and third consistency for type area. The labelling accuracy and type area consistency for the reference data of UMd land cover map is low.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when comparing different land cover datasets?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge encountered when comparing different land cover datasets is the use of varying classification systems, which complicates the comparison process. For instance, when comparing four global land cover maps, the differences in classification systems made it difficult to assess their accuracy and applicability for land surface modeling.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used as a reference for validating land cover maps?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used as a reference for validating land cover maps is the large-scale (1:100 000) land use map of China, produced by the Chinese Academy of Science in 2000. This dataset was used as a truth reference to validate the accuracy of four global land cover maps over China.

Definition.Question: How is 'land cover classification' defined in land surface modeling and mapping?
Definition.Answer: Land cover classification in land surface modeling and mapping refers to the categorization of the Earth's surface based on its physical and biological cover. It involves the use of a classification system, which may vary across different studies, to map land cover at different scales. A unified legend system is often needed to compare different land cover datasets and ensure compatibility with well-recognized systems used in land surface modeling.

Definition.Question: What constitutes 'remote sensing' in the collection of land-use data?
Definition.Answer: Remote sensing in the collection of land-use data involves the use of satellite imagery, such as Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM, to acquire information about the Earth's surface. It is a key technique for producing land-use maps and is employed in large-scale surveys and environmental monitoring, allowing researchers to observe and analyze land-cover changes over time.

Comparison.Question: How do the data sources used in the Chinese Academy of Sciences 1:100000 land use dataset compare to those used in the GLC 2000 project in terms of data accuracy and classification systems?
Comparison.Answer: The Chinese Academy of Sciences 1:100000 land use dataset is based on Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM remote sensing data, employing a detailed classification system with six primary categories and 31 secondary categories. The GLC 2000 project, on the other hand, uses a global land cover map coordinated by the Global Vegetation Monitoring Unit, with its classification system. The GLC 2000 is noted for higher accuracy in comparison to other global maps like MODIS and UMd, whereas the Chinese dataset is recognized for high precision within China.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using the MODIS land cover map versus the IGBP global land cover dataset for land surface modeling in China?
Comparison.Answer: The MODIS land cover map faces challenges related to type area consistency and sub-fraction overall accuracy, ranking second and third, respectively, compared to the GLC 2000. The IGBP dataset, while having good labeling accuracy, suffers from local labeling errors and only third in area consistency. Both datasets struggle with the requirement of a classification system compatible with land surface modeling needs, as indicated by the need to reclassify using a unified system.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges of land-use data collection from the differing classification systems used in global land cover maps?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges of land-use data collection include difficulties in comparing datasets due to varying classification systems, which affects the accuracy and reliability of data for land surface modeling. There is a need to align classification systems with well-recognized ones to improve consistency across datasets.

Interpretation.Question: How might the temporal and spatial features of land-use change impact the methodologies used for data collection in regional land-use studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The temporal and spatial features of land-use change necessitate methodologies that integrate both spatial patterns and temporal processes to effectively capture regional characteristics. This may involve using dynamic regionalization to understand changes over time and space.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the regional differentiation of land-use change in China, and how might this affect data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The regional differentiation of land-use change in China is influenced by the varied physical environments and vast land areas, which not only impact social and economic development but also influence global change. These factors necessitate tailored data collection methods that consider regional characteristics to accurately map and analyze land-use changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of utilizing Landsat TM digital images data for land-use change analysis in terms of revealing temporal and spatial features?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing Landsat TM digital images data for land-use change analysis allows for the division of dynamic regionalization, effectively revealing temporal and spatial features of land-use change and laying the foundation for studying regional scale land-use changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes can be expected from employing a unified legend system for evaluating land cover datasets over China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a unified legend system for evaluating land cover datasets over China facilitates the comparison and evaluation process, allowing for the use of a large-scale land use map as reference data, which helps validate the accuracy of different land cover maps.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of creating a comprehensive land cover map for China using remote sensing data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefits include providing improved land cover information crucial for scientific studies and environmental monitoring, as well as supporting land, ecological, and hydrological modeling, carbon and water cycle studies, and global climatic change research.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of assessing regional differentiation in land-use change within China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Assessing regional differentiation in land-use change is significant because it helps to reveal the temporal and spatial features of land-use change, laying a foundation for understanding regional scale changes and informing policies that impact both social and economic development and global environmental change.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to convert satellite remote sensing data into land-use classifications, while ensuring high precision and consistency across different regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A hierarchical land cover classification system based on satellite remote sensing data such as Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM can be employed. This involves organizing data into different layers representing various land-use categories, ensuring precision by using a consistent classification system across regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can data from different satellite sources be integrated to provide a comprehensive understanding of land-use changes over time in a given area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To integrate data from different satellite sources, one approach is to use multiple datasets like Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data, as done for acquiring land-use information for specific years. By combining data from various sources, temporal changes in land use can be effectively monitored and analyzed.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to evaluate the accuracy of multiple land cover datasets over a specific region, and how can these datasets be compared to a reference map?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps include aggregating the datasets by reclassifying them using a unified legend system, then using a large-scale reference map, such as the 1:100 000 land cover map of China, to compare and validate the datasets. This process involves assessing classification consistency and accuracy against the reference data.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the effective integration of satellite remote sensing data for high-accuracy land-use mapping in diverse regions?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies that enable effective integration include using a hierarchical land cover classification system based on satellite remote sensing data like Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM, as well as CBERS-1 data for acquiring land-use information.

Enablement.Question: How does the application of a unified classification system enhance the validation of various global land cover datasets over a specific region?
Enablement.Answer: The application of a unified classification system allows for the reclassification and aggregation of different land cover maps, facilitating comparison and evaluation against a reference map, such as the 1:100 000 land cover map of China, to assess accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in achieving high accuracy in land cover maps used for environmental monitoring?
Expectation.Answer: The four maps used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. The accuracies of all the datasets cannot meet the requirements of land surface modelling. The classification system of the reference data needs to be transferred to a well-recognized one that has been used commonly in land surface modelling.

Expectation.Question: What expectations could be set for the integration of remote sensing data in evaluating land-use changes over large regions?
Expectation.Answer: Integration of remote sensing data is expected to reveal regional land-use change characteristics on the pattern of dynamic process and dynamic process of pattern, highlighting conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change which lays the foundation to draw the dynamic zones.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a need to develop a new land cover map despite the availability of existing maps?
Expectation.Answer: The possibility of developing a new land cover map whose classification is compatible with a well-accepted legend system but whose accuracy is more reliable motivates the study. The current maps have different classification systems and their accuracies do not fully meet the requirements of land surface modelling.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using satellite remote sensing data like Landsat and CBERS-1 for capturing land-use changes over a vast and diverse region such as China?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of satellite remote sensing data such as Landsat TM and CBERS-1 is considered effective for capturing land-use changes in China due to its ability to cover large areas and provide consistent data over time. These datasets helped in identifying regional differentiation and rapid changes in land use across different regions of China, which is crucial for understanding both local and global environmental changes.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges in ensuring the accuracy and consistency of land cover maps when comparing datasets with different classification systems and resolutions?
Judgmental.Answer: One of the main challenges is the difficulty in comparing datasets that use different classification systems, which can lead to inconsistencies. Additionally, varying resolutions can affect the accuracy of the datasets, as seen in the evaluation of four global land cover maps where different accuracies were observed. The need to align classification systems to a well-recognized standard is crucial for improving consistency and accuracy in land surface modeling.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how satellite remote sensing is utilized to capture detailed land-use data effectively over vast areas.
Assertion.Answer: Satellite remote sensing, such as using Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM, allows for capturing large-scale data efficiently by providing high-resolution images that can be analyzed to classify land use into multiple categories. This method has been effectively used to create detailed datasets like the 1:100 000 land use map of China.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure how different classification systems affect the accuracy and comparison of land cover datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Different classification systems can make comparison challenging as they may not align perfectly. For instance, the four popular land cover maps used different systems, which complicated their evaluation. Reclassifying them using a unified legend system helps in comparing and evaluating the datasets more effectively.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in data classification systems when comparing multiple land cover datasets and suggest potential methods for alignment.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in data classification systems include differing classification systems among datasets, making comparisons difficult. A suggested method for alignment is aggregating maps by reclassifying them using a unified legend system, as indicated in the evaluation of four land cover datasets over China.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the various satellite remote sensing data sources used for land-use information acquisition and their significance in environmental research.
Request/Directive.Answer: Various satellite remote sensing data sources used for land-use information acquisition include Landsat MSS, TM, ETM, and CBERS-1. These sources are significant as they provide detailed land-use change data, essential for studying regional scale land-use changes, terrestrial surface material cycles, and global environmental change.
